Pogor |birth_date = August 20, 1833 |birth_place = [[Iași]], [[Moldavia]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1906|03|20|1833|08|20}} |death_place = Bucium-Iași, [[Kingdom of Romania]] |school_tradition = ''[[Junimea]]'', [[Evolutionism]], [[Positivism]], [[Environmental determinism]], [[Liberal conservatism]], [[Freethought]] |main_interests = [[philosophy of history]], [[Romanian philosophy]], [[Buddhist studies]] |influences = [[Henry Thomas Buckle]], [[Auguste Comte]], [[Arthur Schopenhauer]], [[Voltaire]] |influenced = [[Titu Maiorescu]], [[Theodor Rosetti]], [[A. D. Xenopol]] |notable_ideas = |signature = }}
'''Vasile V. Pogor''' ([[Francization|Francized]] ''Basile Pogor''; August 20, 1833 – March 20, 1906) was a [[Moldavia]]n, later [[Romania]]n poet, philosopher, translator and [[Liberal conservatism|liberal conservative]] politician, one of the founders of ''[[Junimea]]'' literary society. Raised in the aristocratic circle of [[Iași]], and educated in the [[Second French Empire|French Empire]], he had a career in law. He was a civil servant during the [[United Principalities]] regime, held seats and commissions in the [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Assembly of Deputies]], and, after the proclamation of the [[Kingdom of Romania]], was Mayor of Iași City. Although he had a major role in creating the [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880–1918)|Conservative Party]], by fusing together the various "White" political clubs and [[Masonic Lodge]]s, Pogor was more loyal to the ''Junimist'' inner faction, and stood by it when it split with the other Conservatives.
An [[Irreligion|irreligious]] [[Evolutionism|evolutionist]], and taking an interest in [[Buddhist studies]], Pogor represented the [[Positivism|Positivist]] cell at ''Junimea''. He was also one of the first locals to study the work of [[Henry Thomas Buckle]], integrating Bucklean concepts into ''Junimea''{{'}}s critique of [[nation building]]. He supported Romania's [[Westernization]] within a conservative framework, tempering nationalist presumptions and valuing a culturally pluralistic society. The notoriously indolent and improvident Pogor had a preference for [[orality]], and was sought after for his [[Voltaire|Voltairian]] wit. He left few written works, and many unfulfilled projects, but influenced [[Romanian literature]] as a cultural promoter, sponsor, and the first local expert on [[Charles Baudelaire]]. He was known to his ''Junimea'' colleagues as a one-man "contemporary library".
Pogor's final decades were spent away from the national scene, although he still took on assignments in the Conservative and ''Junimist'' chapters of [[Iași County]]. ''[[Casa Pogor]]'', his main residence, is closely associated with ''Junimist'' history. Although sold by its debt-stricken owner in 1901, it was revived in the 1970s as a literary history museum, theater venue and concert hall. Married to the [[Russian nobility|Russian aristocrat]] Elena Hartingh, Pogor left an illegitimate son, Vasile Panopol.
==Biography==
===Origins and childhood=== According to various accounts, the Pogors were a clan of [[yeomen]] from the eponymous [[Răuseni|Pogorăști]], raised into [[Boyars of Wallachia and Moldavia|boyar nobility]] ca. 1820.<ref>Bezviconi, pp. 58–59; Vianu, p. 79</ref> The family's own pedigree claimed otherwise, namely that its members had been "enjoying native privileges" since ancient times.<ref name="gc92">Călinescu, p. 92</ref> On the basis of such claims, Vasile Pogor Sr had a steady climb through the Moldavian civilian and military bureaucracy: he began his career as a ''[[Serdar (Ottoman rank)|Serdar]]'' (1819), before being made a ''[[Comis]]'' for life.<ref name="gc92"/> During his 1816–1823 mission into the [[Bessarabian Governorate]], [[Russian Empire]], Pogor kidnapped Zoița Cerchez, granddaughter of a local ''[[Clucer]]''.<ref>Bezviconi, p. 59</ref> From this marriage, he had three daughters—Antonia, Eleonora, Smaranda—and a son, the future poet.<ref>Călinescu, pp. 92, 437. See also Bezviconi, pp. 59, 87</ref> By the time of his birth, the family owned large boyar estates in both [[Vaslui County]] (including [[Vulturești, Vaslui|Buhăiești]] and [[Drânceni|Râșești]]) and Bessarabia.<ref name="gc92"/>
As a political poet in the [[Age of Revolution]], ''Comis'' Pogor looked back with disgust on the late [[Phanariotes|Phanariote]] period and the [[Filiki Eteria|Eterist]] invasion, satirizing the ambitions of [[Greeks of Romania|Greek immigrants]] to Moldavia.<ref name="gc92"/> In the late 1830s, he would be equally opposed to the Moldavian ''status quo'', criticizing the heavy-handed [[List of rulers of Moldavia|Moldavian sovereign]] [[Mihail Sturdza]]. His rhyming pamphlets envisaged [[equality before the law]], their author having signed up to the "Confederative Conspiracy", planned by Moldavia's [[Liberalism and radicalism in Romania|proto-liberal boyardom]].<ref name="tv80">Vianu, p. 80</ref> He still held several high political-judicial offices in the last quarter of Sturdza, including the ''[[Agha (Ottoman Empire)|Agie]]'' and the Justice Department chairmanship.<ref>Călinescu, pp. 91, 92</ref>
Pogor Sr's worldview also owed much to his familiarity with [[French literature]]. He corresponded with [[François-René de Chateaubriand|Chateaubriand]], wishing to publish his poetry in a Moldavian edition,<ref>Călinescu, p. 91</ref> but is probably best known as Voltaire's first [[Romanian-language]] translator. His version of the ''[[Henriade]]'' was published in neighboring [[Wallachia]] by the liberal intellectual [[Ion Heliade Rădulescu]].<ref>Călinescu, p. 91; Vianu, p. 80</ref> It and other translations by the ''Comis'' (''[[Zaïre (play)|Zaïre]]'', ''[[Poème sur le désastre de Lisbonne|Désastre de Lisbonne]]'') may prove that Pogor the younger was already familiar with Voltaire and Voltarianism from early childhood.<ref>Călinescu, pp. 91, 436</ref>
[[File:Veisa and Pogor take the stagecoach ride to Kraków, 1849 ILR 440.jpg|thumb|340px|Teodor Veisa's drawing of the 1849 departure for [[Kraków]]]] Born in Iași, the Moldavian capital, Vasile Jr was selected for the most modern forms of education available to Moldavians living in the 1840s. He first attended the liberal arts' school of Frenchman Malgoverné, and, in addition to discovering an interest in literature, became a skilled amateur draftsman.<ref>Călinescu, p. 437; Vianu, pp. 80, 82</ref> In October 1849, young Pogor took the [[stagecoach]] ride to [[Kraków]], and then the train to [[Paris]], accompanied by the boyar heirs Heraclide, Porfiriu, Miclescu and Teodor Veisa, and chaperoned by Malgoverné himself. The scene of their departure from Iași is preserved in a sketch drawing by Veisa, which shows the enthusiastic adolescents leaning out the carriage doors.<ref>Călinescu, pp. 437, 440</ref>
===French and German education=== Pogor completed his education in France. He is widely seen as formed by [[Education in France|French education]], but, according to cultural sociologist [[Zigu Ornea]], this is only part of the story: Pogor did not graduate from a ''[[Secondary education in France|lycée]]'', but was actually trained at a [[Germanophone]] boarding school; was not introduced to [[Bonapartism]], but to "the ideological principles of [[Bourbon Restoration|Restoration]]".<ref>Ornea (I), p. 143</ref> As argued by author Gheorghe Manolache, Pogor was one of those who saw [[French culture]] as "speculative", and sought to amend its influence with [[Culture of Germany|German]] or [[Anglophone]] borrowings.<ref name="gmschiller24">{{ro icon}} Gheorghe Manolache, [https://web.archive.org/web/20140714130049/http://www.revistatransilvania.ro/arhiva/2005/pdf/numarul10-11/art9_literaritate_si_literalitate_sau_arta_de_a_traduce_pe_schiller.pdf "Sub patronajul Junimii din Iași (1863–1874). Literaritate și literalitate sau arta de a traduce pe Schiller"] in ''Transilvania'', Nr. 10–11/2005, p. 24</ref> In late 1851, he took an extended study trip through the [[German Confederation]], in lieu of service in the [[Moldavian military forces]]. The Moldavian state granted him dispensation, and awarded him the rank of [[Cadet]].<ref name="gc437">Călinescu, p. 437</ref>
Pogor was subsequently enlisted at the [[University of Paris]] Law School, where he took his [[Doctor of law|doctorate in law]].<ref name="lvvp-fiul">{{ro icon}} Lucian Vasiliu, [https://web.archive.org/web/20040222022006/http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/VASILIUdec3.html "Vasile Pogor-fiul"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', December 2003</ref><ref>Călinescu, p. 419</ref> His contact with the Parisian salons was of major formative importance: he was an avid reader and, as literary historian [[Tudor Vianu]] notes, "always open to new things, ready to defeat prejudice", if rather indiscriminate.<ref>Vianu, pp. 80–81</ref> Pogor's one constant was the study of the classics: he reread [[Homer]]'s ''[[Iliad]]'' and ''[[Odyssey]]'' once every year.<ref>Călinescu, p. 437; Vianu, p. 81</ref> His other known pursuits were non-academic. Pogor discovered ''[[comédie en vaudeville]]'' theater, kept company with mature women, and began fantasizing about writing his own novels and short stories.<ref name="gc437"/>
The Pogors enjoyed high political profiles during and after the [[Crimean War]], when the Moldavian and Wallachian principalities became a condominium of the [[Great Powers]]. Before his death in 1857, Pogor Sr was head of the [[appellate court]] (''Divanul de apel'', later ''Curtea de apel''), and one of the boyars tasked with welcoming in the foreign overseers.<ref name="gc92"/> Upon his return to Moldavia, the young lawyer became sole owner of a palatial residence, ''[[Casa Pogor]]'', built by his father in 1850, on land previously owned by the Cerchez and Coroi boyars.<ref name="cccasele4">{{ro icon}} Constantin Coroiu, [http://revistacultura.ro/cultura.php?articol=4884 "Casele scriitorilor (IV)"], in ''Cultura'', Nr. 247, October 2009</ref> He also took assignments in the judicial apparatus. He was a judge in Iași from 1857 to 1858, and a member of the appellate court after March 1859.<ref name="gc437"/> Although cutting the figure of an eccentric among the stern bureaucrats, he managed to impress [[Costache Negruzzi]], his hierarchical superior and celebrated novelist. In his account, Pogor displayed "something rare in our folk": "a great feeling for justice".<ref name="ipafis">{{ro icon}} [[Ioana Pârvulescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/index.pl/un_loc_gol_pe_afi "Un loc gol pe afiș"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 41/2006</ref>
The Pogors still maintained close links with the areas on the other side of the [[Prut River]]: Antonia Pogor became the wife of Bessarabian boyar Dumitru Bantîș.<ref>Bezviconi, p. 87; Călinescu, p. 437</ref> When he married the Bessarabian heiress Elena Hartingh, Vasile established a connection with [[Russian nobility]]. His father-in-law was a Karl "Scarlat" Hartingh (or Garting), owner of an estate in [[Pohrebeni]].<ref>Bezviconi, pp. 59, 116; Călinescu, p. 437</ref> Elena's grandfather was [[Ivan Markovich Garting]], an [[Finns|ethnic Finn]] who had served as [[Bessarabian Governorate|Bessarabian Governor]]; her grandmother, "Elenco" Hartinga, was closely related to the high-ranking boyardom of Moldavia.<ref>Bezviconi, p. 116; [[Nicolae Iorga]], "Testamentul unei nepoate de fiică, mame și surori de Domni moldoveni", in ''Revista Istorică'', Nr. 7–9/1931, pp. 153–163</ref>
===''Junimea'' creation=== [[File:Iaşi , Romanian Literature Museum (House Pogor) 5.JPG|thumb|300px|''[[Casa Pogor]]'' in 2009]] From early 1859, Moldavia and Wallachia formed a single Romanian state, known as the "[[United Principalities]]" and ruled upon by ''[[Domnitor]]'' [[Alexandru Ioan Cuza]]. Still employed by the Moldavian appellate court under Cuza's regime, Pogor objected to the fiscal policies of [[Prime Minister of Romania|Premier]] [[Nicolae Crețulescu]], and resigned in September 1863, shortly followed by his colleague [[Alexandru Papadopol-Calimah]].<ref>X., "Năpăstiile Uniriĭ. IV. Suferințele Moldoveĭ", in ''[[Românul|Romănulŭ]]'', September 25, 1863, p. 848</ref> By then, he had resumed his literary projects. The first achievement of Pogor's work as a translator was his retelling of [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe|Goethe]]'s ''[[Faust: The First Part of the Tragedy|Faust I]]'', with [[Nicolai Skelitti]] as co-author, saw print in 1862.<ref name="tv81">Vianu, p. 81</ref><ref name="cjnoica">{{ro icon}} Corina Jiva, [http://www.romlit.ro/index.pl/suntem_inca_in_anul_noica "Suntem încă în anul Noica"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 50/2009</ref><ref name="dmmodelul">{{ro icon}} [[Dan Mănucă]], [http://www.romlit.ro/index.pl/modelul_junimist "Modelul junimist"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 48/2008</ref> Samples of his own poetry were published by the pro-Cuza magazine ''Din Moldova'', whose editor was a future enemy, the Romantic novelist and scholar [[Bogdan Petriceicu Hasdeu]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Teodor Vârgolici, [http://www.romlit.ro/index.pl/revistele_lui_b._p._hasdeu2 "Revistele lui B. P. Hasdeu"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 30/2009</ref>
The United Principalities era saw Pogor's activity blending into the cultural projects of ''Junimea'' literary society. Founded in stages ca. 1863, that club was originally focused on literary debates and popular education. Its founders were five young graduates, all but one of them boyars. Pogor and [[Theodor Rosetti]] were French-trained; [[Petre P. Carp]] and [[Iacob Negruzzi]] (Costache's son) had studied in the German Confederation. The fifth was [[Titu Maiorescu]], an upper-middle-class intellectual trained in both French and German schools, generally seen as the leading voice of ''Junimism'', the cultural and political concept.<ref>Călinescu, pp. 397, 399, 419; Ornea (I), pp. 1–42; Vianu, pp. 6–7</ref>
Little is known about the first years of ''Junimism''. The five founders left only a handful of notes on the subject, and discouraged others from investigating the topic. Pogor himself mystified on the subject: he laughed off the historiographic attempts and, playfully reusing a literary cliché, informed newer members of the club that "''Junimea''{{'}}s origin is lost in the mist of time".<ref name="mdssocsec2">{{ro icon}} [[Mihai Dim. Sturdza]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20040810130412/http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/STURDZAiul4.html "Junimea, societate secretă (II)"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', July 2004</ref><ref>Ornea (I), p. 13</ref> His version of events subverted other accounts, including the vague memoirs of Iacob Negruzzi. Pogor thus claimed that ''Junimea'' existed in large part because of him. In Pogor's account, the first manifestation of what would become ''Junimea'' was a study group comprising himself, Skelitti, Papadopol-Calimah, [[Theodor Aslan]], [[Iorgu Gane]], [[Ioan Ianov]], and some other prominent Iași intellectuals; to the irritation of other ''Junimists'', he constantly backdated ''Junimea''{{'}}s existence to 1862.<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 14–15</ref> His account is not validated by the written records, and other sources (themselves scanty) suggest that, although invited by Maiorescu, Pogor did not in fact attend the so-called "first ''Junimea'' meeting" (February 9, 1864).<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 15–16</ref>
Pogor was nonetheless present at other (possibly earlier) gatherings, which gave a more formal status to the reunions. In his half-mythical narrative of events, presented at later ''Junimea'' banquets, Pogor insisted that the first day of ''Junimism'' was a Friday (''vineri''), and that, as such, the club was under the divine patronage of [[Venus (mythology)|Venus]].<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 34–35</ref> Based on the available reconstructions of events, the club's name seems to have been selected by Rosetti, and ceremoniously validated by Pogor—whom the other founders already recognized as their ''[[Wiktionary:enfant terrible|enfant terrible]]''.<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 17–18, 30, 36–37; Vianu, pp. 18, 81</ref> The resulting society had little in the way of a published program, but the generic lines, including efforts to rationalize the [[History of the Romanian language|spelling of Romanian]] and to provide affordable education, survive in one of I. Negruzzi's letters.<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 19–21</ref>
Pogor's large townhouse is popularly understood as the ''Junimea'' headquarters, but, at least initially, the club also met at Maiorescu's place, and occasionally at Negruzzi's.<ref name="Ornea I, p. 34">Ornea (I), p. 34</ref> Indirectly, the young boyar helped found the club's own printing press, which was donated to Maiorescu by Pogor's Bessarabian cousin, the philanthropist [[Nicolae Ștefan Casso]], and, after 1867, the literary sheet ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]''.<ref name="gmschiller24"/><ref>Ornea (I), pp. 27–28, 43; Vianu, p. 8</ref> The latter's mailing address was ''Casa Pogor''.<ref name="cccasele4"/><ref name="spirituljun">{{ro icon}} [http://curierul-iasi.ro/vasile-pogor-spiritul-junimii-in-palatul-roznovanu-4289 "Vasile Pogor, spiritul Junimii în Palatul Roznovanu"], in ''[[Curierul de Iași]]'', September 13, 2011</ref> Pogor himself managed the publishing firm, but did a notoriously poor job. Described by Ornea as "a man for all the hasty projects" and as an "absent-minded" individual, Pogor ran heavy debts and frequently changed managers ([[Ioan Mire Melik]], [[Al. Farra]] etc.).<ref name="Ornea I, p. 28">Ornea (I), p. 28</ref> The ''Junimist'' publishing house was barely keeping afloat once Pogor took money out of the budget to create a book store—one of such niche appeal as to make Pogor the only buyer of his books.<ref name="lvvp-fiul"/><ref name="Ornea I, p. 28"/>
===Provocateur, anthologist, lecturer=== At ''Junimea'', Pogor was a picturesque figure. Ornea suggests that, despite being a respectable boyar and the oldest among the founders, Pogor was also the most "child-like" in his reactions.<ref>Ornea (I), p. 30</ref> Witnesses recall that he was always amused by the literary works presented for analysis, laughing "till his new teeth jumped out of his mouth", and casually reclining on a sofa as the debates were taking place.<ref>Călinescu, p. 436</ref> Negruzzi recalled that, in defiance for "any social habit", Pogor left his guests unattended to read his books; he writes that, on first impression, Pogor appeared "cheeky and missing something upstairs".<ref name="ipafis"/> Moreover, Pogor embarrassed his friends with his obscene anecdotes, his name-calling, and his occasional outbursts, during which he would hurl his cape at them.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ioana Pârvulescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/index.pl/mai_avem_azi_un_maiorescu_iii "Mai avem azi un Maiorescu? (III)"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 21/2009</ref>
However, Pogor's lolling habit and thundering laughter soon became fashionable, and his yawning during the others' recitations was intentionally loud, provocative and contagious.<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 36, 38–41</ref> He justified such heckling with the expression ''Entre qui veut, reste qui peut'' (French for "enters who wishes, stays on who can stand it"), later a ''Junimea'' motto.<ref>Ornea (I), p. 39; {{ro icon}} [[Ioana Pârvulescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/index.pl/la_nceput_a_fost_deviza.. "La început a fost deviza..."], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 38/2006</ref> The slogan resonated with the ''caracudă'' ("small game") wing of ''Junimea''—mostly passive youngsters who came in for entertainment, and who, Ornea notes, were "apparently immune to beauty and ignorant".<ref>Ornea (I), p. 41</ref>
For all his unorthodox stances, Pogor was regarded by all his colleagues as a towering intellect, and referred to as "the contemporary library".<ref name="tv81"/> The ''Junimist'' colleagues repeatedly noted that he was the man to bring in not just irreverence, but also genuine innovation.<ref name="ipafis"/> Vianu describes his "merciless gibes" as stemming from a conviction that the others were too uptight, and in general from a rejection of "dogmatism"; Pogor, he writes, would "embrace in turn all sorts of attitudes".<ref>Vianu, p. 18</ref> Another scholar, [[Șerban Cioculescu]], describes Pogor as by character "a free, unambitious, spirit, an [[Epicureanism|epicurean]] of intelligence".<ref>Cioculescu, p. 6</ref> Similarly, Ornea cautions: "If Maiorescu has conferred a consistent substance to ''Junimea'', then Pogor gave it a pinch of salt, wit, humor and—an essential element—skepticism, that is to say a sense of relativity."<ref>Ornea (I), p. 40</ref>
Encouraged by the other club members, Pogor became the anthologist of bad journalism and literature, scouring anti-''Junimist'' periodicals and picking out the most amusing enormities and the most embarrassing platitudes. These he then pasted into his ''Dosar'' ("Dossier"), which is for most part a subtle political attack on the "Red" ideology of [[Liberalism and radicalism in Romania|Romanian liberalism]] and [[Romantic nationalism]].<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 35–36</ref> Ornea notes: "those who have discussed the ''Junimea Dossier'' as politics in disguise, practiced by a literary circle that had denied itself—under pain of sanction—any politically derived conversation, they were not at all in the wrong."<ref>Ornea (I), p. 36</ref> Already in 1863, the ''Junimists'' had engaged in battle the literary representatives of Romanian liberalism, including ''Din Moldova''{{'}}s B. P. Hasdeu. The latter dedicated his activity as a journalist to deriding or condemning the ''Junimea'' group, Pogor included, accusing it of standing for values not complementary with the Romanian way: [[cosmopolitanism]] and [[Germanophilia]], [[elitism]] and [[philosemitism]].<ref>Vianu, p. 239</ref>
While these debates gathered in notoriety, Pogor was also joining in the yearly cycle of ''Junimea'' conferences, or ''prelecțiuni''. He, Maiorescu, and Carp were the core group of lecturers during the first age of the ''prelecțiuni''. The subjects were broad and the inspiration spontaneous,<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 22–23; Vianu, pp. 7, 32–33</ref> but the speakers still followed Maiorescu's elaborate ceremonial, which reduced direct contact with the listeners.<ref name="lpmasoneria">{{ro icon}} Liviu Papuc, [https://web.archive.org/web/20080710201511/http://www.sud-est.md/numere/20061123/article_8/ "Masoneria junimistă"], in ''[[Revista Sud-Est]]'', Nr. 4/2006</ref> In 1864, Pogor discussed the [[French Revolution]], and specifically its "impact on modern ideas".<ref name="tv81"/> There was a break in the following year, with Maiorescu having been involved in a sex scandal, but the lecturers returned in 1866, when the common theme was "factors of national life throughout history".<ref>Ornea (I), p. 23</ref> Pogor was also contributing to the ''Junimea'' who's who of Romanian poetry, selecting for reading pieces by the 18th-century boyar [[Ienăchiță Văcărescu]].<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 73–74</ref> At the ''prelecțiuni'', Pogor spoke about [[Ancient Greek art]]; in 1867, about [[Shakespearean tragedy]]; during later cycles, he discovered and introduced for the general public the philosophy of [[Arthur Schopenhauer]].<ref name="tv81"/> Still focused on national identity constructs and the [[philosophy of history]], he promoted at ''Junimea'' the evolutionist treatise ''History of Civilization in England'', by [[Henry Thomas Buckle]].<ref name="arideologia13">{{ro icon}} Alexandru Ruja, [http://www.revistaorizont.ro/arhiva/iunie2011.pdf "Ideologia junimistă"], in ''[[Orizont]]'', Nr. 6/2011, p. 13</ref><ref>Ornea (I), pp. 49, 60, 157, 167–168; Vianu, p. 81</ref>
===Masonic conspirator and "White" organizer=== Meanwhile, Pogor the politician was drawn into secretive, then conspiratorial, work. Pogor in Iași, and Carp in [[Bucharest]], helped organize the February 1866 putsch against the [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] Cuza, and supported the interim government presided upon by both liberal "Reds" and conservative "Whites".<ref>Ornea (I), p. 252</ref> On February 15, the [[Princely Lieutenancy of Romania (1866)|Romanian Regency]] appointed Pogor [[Prefect (Romania)|Prefect]] of [[Iași County]],<ref name="gc437"/> and he was also a regional representative in the [[Chamber of Deputies of Romania|Assembly of Deputies]] ([[Romanian general election, April 1866|quickly elected]] for the drafting of a [[1866 Constitution of Romania|new constitution]]). On April 28, he was elected as one of its secretaries.<ref>Nicolescu, pp. 5–6</ref> For most of the year, he had a noted role in persuading his colleagues to accept [[bicameralism]], and thus contributed to the establishment of the [[Senate of Romania]].<ref>Xenopol, pp. 522–523</ref> In March, he was also sent back to the appellate court, as section president, serving until January 1868.<ref name="gc437"/> According to scholar [[George Călinescu]], he began supplementing his revenue with "multiple and ephemeral" special commissions, including that of [[Certified teacher|teacher certification]] examiner (October 1866).<ref name="gc437"/>
Pogor was received into the [[Freemasonry]] ([[Ancient and Primitive Rite|Oriental Rite of Memphis]], [[Grand Orient de France]]) on March 14, 1866, and, only a year later, reached the 90th Masonic Degree.<ref name="lpmasoneria"/> Within the divided [[Freemasonry in Romania|Romanian Freemasonry]], he sided with the Moldavian [[Masonic Lodge|Lodge]] called "Star of Romania": he was the Orator under Venerable Master Iorgu Sutzu.<ref name="lpmasoneria"/> Joined by most of the ''Junimist'' personalities, this institution would open up a new front against the "Reds", challenging their [[xenophobia]] and [[antisemitism]]. The Lodge opened its ranks to people of various backgrounds, including [[History of the Jews in Romania|Romanian Jews]], but was off-limits to the Moldavian liberals.<ref name="mdssocsec2"/><ref name="lpmasoneria"/> The Lodge members, Pogor and Maiorescu included, set up and helped edit a "White" political sheet, ''Constituțiunea'' ("Constitution"), later ''Gazeta de Iassi''.<ref name="mdssocsec2"/> Initially, the paper joined the ranks of Moldavian regionalists, complaining about Iași's social, cultural, and demographic decline under Romanian rule; however, by March 30, Pogor and Maiorescu had also affiliated with the centralizing [[National Party (Romania)|National Party]], where they talked of finding other roles for the declining former capital.<ref>Xenopol, pp. 487–488, 498–499, 502–504, 506</ref> Against separatists such as Constantin Moruzi and the [[Free and Independent Faction]], they sought a cemented union, proposing the selection of a foreign ruler from [[Romance-speaking Europe]].<ref>Xenopol, pp. 503–504, 506</ref>
With the arrival on the throne of a German prince, [[Carol I of Romania|Carol of Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen]], the anti-Cuza coalition was again divided into competing factions. However, Ornea writes, just two ''Junimist'' leaders had openly engaged in party politics: "Petre Carp and—unbelievably so!—the freaky V. Pogor."<ref>Ornea (I), p. 63</ref> This despite the fact that Iași's Masonic Lodge had become a junior wing of the "White" party, and was portrayed by the local "Red" polemicists as an [[Anti-Christian sentiment|anti-Christian]] fraternity.<ref>Ornea (I), p. 253</ref> No longer committed to the principle of a "Latin" prince, Pogor openly supported the new ''Domnitor''—he was one of 109 deputies (from a total 115) to ratify the [[Romanian prince referendum, 1866|April plebiscite]].<ref>Xenopol, p. 506</ref> The "Star of Romania" Lodge invited Carol to join its ranks and become leader of the unified Freemasonry.<ref name="lpmasoneria"/> Around 1867, against antisemitic agitation by the Free and Independent Faction, the ''Junimist'' core, Pogor included, signed up to a proposal for [[Jewish emancipation]], meaning the Jewish minority's effective naturalization. Probably initiated by the "Star of Romania",<ref name="mdssocsec2"/> their petition asked ''Domnitor'' Carol to "establish legal order" in front of "anarchy", noting that the liberals worked to "kidnap hundreds of Jews".<ref>[[William Evans-Gordon]], [https://archive.org/details/alienimmigrant00evanuoft ''The Alien Immigrant''], pp. 167–168. London: [[Heinemann (publisher)|W. Heinemann]], 1903</ref>
By 1869, Pogor and Carp had also rallied with the Society of Young Dynasticists, which conspired with dissident liberals such as [[Gheorghe Mârzescu]] to elect only monarchists into office—for instance, [[Romanian general election, 1869|during 1869]].<ref>Ioan Dafin, ''Iașii, cultural și social: Amintiri și însemnări'', Vol. II, pp. 80–83. Iași: [[Viața Romînească]], 1929</ref> The early 1870s transformed ''Junimea'' into a moderate conservative political movement, annexed to the "White" wing of the political spectrum. For Maiorescu, theirs was the cause of restoration and order in front of "Red" agitation (the [[Republic of Ploiești]] episode), but also adverse to the "arch-conservatives" who wanted a return of boyar privileges.<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 256–257</ref> Within this setting, Pogor found that his political status progressed quickly: from January 1869 to May 1870, he was president of the appellate court.<ref name="gc437"/> Yet, as Tudor Vianu notes, he still treated political assignments "with a certain indifference."<ref>Vianu, p. 83</ref>
At the beginning of that decade, "White" Premier [[Manolache Costache Epureanu]] opened his cabinet to ''Junimist'' experts, and Pogor was expected to take over a top administrative position. Carp, who negotiated the deal, vouched for Pogor's competence.<ref>Călinescu, pp. 400; Ornea (I), pp. 63–64, 80, 254–255</ref> Pogor resigned before the so-called "Hen and Fledgling" cabinet was even sworn in.<ref>Călinescu, p. 400; Ornea (I), p. 254; Vianu, p. 83</ref> Reportedly, he complained of [[dorsopathy]], leaving Maiorescu worried that he had developed [[neurosyphilis]]. Pogor declared himself cured within a few days, announcing that he was ready to take over as Romania's [[Ministry of Education, Research, Youth and Sport (Romania)|Minister of Education]].<ref>Călinescu, pp. 400–401</ref> According to various sources, he actually held the office, if only briefly.<ref>Bacalbașa, pp. 19–20; Șuțu, p. 239</ref> His unexpected renunciation cleared the path for Maiorescu's own political ascent, moving him from a position in the background to the "Fledgling" Education portfolio.<ref>Călinescu, pp. 400–401; Ornea (I), pp. 254–256</ref>
===''Convorbiri Literare'' editor and 1871 mandate=== [[File:Vasile Pogor in 1873 ILR 440.jpg|thumb|190px|Pogor in 1873]] Pogor still was a notable participant in polemics, taking Maiorescu's side. One such case was that of disputes between the ''Junimists'' and an ultra-"White" group headed by Epureanu. The latter wanted to institute an authoritarian regime favoring the upper class and favored some exotic policies—[[Capital punishment in Romania|generalizing the death penalty]] or opening the country to massive [[Germans of Romania|German colonization]]. Probably wishing to maintain "White" unity, the ''Junimists'', including Pogor, gave reluctant backing to the Epureanu program, and became targets for "Red" sarcasm, and were even chided by the dominant conservative club, that of [[Lascăr Catargiu]].<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 258–262. See also Bacalbașa, pp. 25–35</ref> Pogor was also chairman of the ''Junimist'' "Society for Sending Young Romanians on Study Trips", noted for discovering and sponsoring the future [[Atheism|atheistic]] philosopher [[Vasile Conta]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Sorin Lavric]], [http://www.romlit.ro/index.pl/plectrul_fatalitii "Plectrul fatalității"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 13/2012</ref>
In parallel with his political chores, Pogor took up the task of translating some of [[Charles Baudelaire]]'s ''[[Les Fleurs du mal|Flowers of Evil]]''. "Don Juan in Hell" and "Gipsies on the Road" were both published by ''Convorbiri'' in March 1870.<ref name="dmmodelul"/><ref>Călinescu, p. 437; [[Paul Cernat]], ''Avangarda românească și complexul periferiei: primul val'', p. 8. Bucharest: [[Cartea Românească]], 2007. {{ISBN|978-973-23-1911-6}}</ref> Before this moment, Baudelaire's work had been entirely unknown to Romanians,<ref name="tv81"/> and casually ignored by Maiorescu, who preferred [[German Romanticism]].<ref>Călinescu, pp. 412–413, 437, 685</ref> Later, Pogor published adapted samples from other modern French figures ([[Victor Hugo]], [[Théophile Gautier]], [[Leconte de Lisle]], [[Sully Prudhomme]], [[Jean Richepin]])<ref name="gc437"/> alternating them with classical works by [[Horace]] ([[Odes (Horace)|Ode III.26]], in 1871)<ref name="nlhoratiu537">{{ro icon}} Nicolae Laslo, [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/gandromanesc/1935/BCUCLUJ_FP_BALP73_1935_003_011_012.pdf "Horațiu în literatura română"], in ''[[Gând Românesc]]'', Nr. 11–12/1935, p. 537 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> and [[Virgil]] (''Copa'', in 1873).<ref>{{ro icon}} M. Strajan, [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/transilvania/1904/BCUCLUJ_FP_279996_1904_035_002.pdf "Virgiliu"], in ''Transilvania'', Nr. 2/1904, p. 70 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> He and other ''Convorbiri Literare'' writers pioneered translations from [[American literature]], most notably from the stories of [[Edgar Allan Poe]].<ref name="dmmodelul"/><ref>{{ro icon}} [[Paul Cernat]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20120317053638/http://www.romaniaculturala.ro/articol.php?cod=12049 "E. Lovinescu sub presiunea posterității. Inconsecvență? Mai degrabă simț al independenței"], in ''Cultura'', Nr. 8/2009</ref> This was still just a fraction of Pogor's activity in the field. His papers reveal that he had also tried, but failed, to translate, among others, ''[[Rameau's Nephew]]'' by [[Denis Diderot|Diderot]], [[Ludwig Uhland]]'s "The Minstrel's Curse", and [[Constantin-François Chassebœuf|Volney]]'s ''Les Ruines''.<ref name="gc437, 1000"/>
In addition to his translation projects, ''Convorbiri Literare'' hosted his original works, beginning with the autobiographical piece "A Marquise's Pastel" (September 1868).<ref name="lvvp-fiul"/> In January 1871, still independent of party politics, the journal was reorganized as a cultural monthly. Pogor was assigned to the editorial committee, a triumvirate also grouping Maiorescu and Negruzzi.<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 65–66</ref> He and Maiorescu resigned soon after, alleging that Negruzzi had failed to consult them about the editorial policy, possibly because of a polemical review inserted by [[Ștefan Vârgolici]].<ref>Ornea (I), p. 66</ref> This did not imply that they would cease to write for ''Convorbiri''. Also that year, the magazine published a poem by Pogor's deceased father, newly discovered in the family archive.<ref name="tv80"/> In October, when ''Junimea'' finally liquidated its publishing venture, Pogor was asked to take care of the debts and return the debit.<ref name="Ornea I, p. 28"/> Without Negruzzi's knowledge, the enterprise was purchased by the Jewish businessman Herșcu Goldner.<ref name="gmschiller24"/>
Meanwhile, Hasdeu's ''Columna lui Traian'' paper had made it its mission to host samples from Pogor's poetry, to show its readers how one was not supposed to versify.<ref>{{ro icon}} Gheorghe Mocuța, [http://www.revista-studii-uvvg.ro/files/revista_III_4.pdf "Centenar Bogdan Petriceicu Hasdeu"], in the [[Vasile Goldiș West University of Arad]] ''Studii de Știință și Cultură'', Nr. 4 (11), December 2007, p. 99; Ornea (II), p. 287</ref> Hasdeu registered a moral victory when a short poem by an "M. I. Ellias" saw print in the July 15 issue of ''Convorbiri Literare''. With Maiorescu in Bucharest, the piece had earned the approval of both Pogor and his rival, [[Mihai Eminescu]].<ref>Ornea (II), p. 289</ref> It was, in fact, a prank. Hasdeu had improvised the poem himself (calling it "a rhyming frivolity") so as to prove that ''Junimea'' writers lacked taste and patriotic feeling—"there is not a [[Wiktionary:galimatias|galimatias]] [...] that ''Convorbiri Literare'' won't rush in to grab and hold by its bosom, provided one essential condition is met: that it does not include anything Romanian."<ref>Ornea (II), pp. 288–289</ref>
The ''Junimist'' faction made its formal entry into [[Parliament of Romania|Parliament]] after the [[Romanian general election, 1871|1871 election]]. As a result of these, the nation's Assembly of Deputies included five ''Junimist'' members, voting with the "White" group: Pogor, Maiorescu, Negruzzi, N. Gane, [[Gheorghe Racoviță]].<ref name="Ornea I, p. 258">Ornea (I), p. 258</ref> After the partial elections of 1874, they were joined by two others: Carp (previously serving ''Domnitor'' Carol as a diplomat) and Th. Rosetti.<ref name="Ornea I, p. 258"/> As noted by his contemporaries, Pogor, even though selected as Vice President of the Assembly,<ref name="spirituljun"/> was not an asset for the ''Junimist'' faction. [[George Panu]], the ''Junimea'' memoirist, noted that Pogor was an incompetent public speaker, rarely present at the rostrum. When he did address the Assembly, Pogor was unrecognizable and "embarrassing", turning "pale as a cadaver", his voice "shaking" with timidity.<ref name="gc441">Călinescu, p. 441</ref>
===Bucharest relocation and 1875 mandate=== Pogor's own prolonged absences, like the political passions of other ''Junimist'' founders, were a cause for concern in Iași. Those who had stayed behind, Negruzzi included, complained that the club was dying out, with the reunions turning into glorified tea parties.<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 85–95</ref> As such, all the ''Junimea'' founders except Negruzzi were absent from the club's meeting on February 25, 1872.<ref>Ornea (I), p. 31</ref>
In the end, when Negruzzi also accepted a government job, the club was reestablished to the national capital, Bucharest. The small Iași section survived for a while as a ''caracudă'' hotspot, experiencing what Ornea called "a slow and embarrassing ending".<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 95–97</ref> Pogor paid the occasional visit and, according to ''caracudă'' leader [[Nicolae Gane]], behaved with restraint ("against his nature").<ref>Ornea (I), p. 96</ref> This was the time of Pogor's polemics with Eminescu. The latter, a voice of [[national conservatism]], and recognized by posterity as the Romanian [[national poet]], read out his fantasy novella ''[[Sărmanul Dionis]]''. As ''Junimea'' minutes will attest, Pogor and Maiorescu found the work to be all to cryptic, but still gave approval for its publishing.<ref>Valentin Coșereanu, "Jurnalul Junimii"], in ''Caiete Critice'', Nr. 6/2010, p. 23</ref> For a few months in 1874, Pogor allowed the penniless poet to lodge with him. Sources diverge on whether Eminescu lived at ''Casa Pogor''<ref name="cccasele4"/> or another one of the politician's townhouses, which has since been demolished.<ref>{{ro icon}} Valeriu Gherghel, [http://www.ziaruldeiasi.ro/opinii/a-locuit-cu-adevarat-eminescu-in-casa-pogor~ni4tu9 "A locuit cu adevărat Eminescu în Casa Pogor?"], in ''[[Ziarul de Iași]]'', August 26, 2008</ref>
By the close of his mandate in the Assembly, Pogor had involved himself in the [[Strousberg Affair]] dispute, suggesting (unsuccessfully) that ministers found guilty of misdeeds should have their revenue retained by the state.<ref>Nicolescu, p. 129</ref> The Catargiu cabinet was facing a [[motion of no confidence]] over its [[stamp act]] proposal, with Pogor and Carp working to keep the two debates separate.<ref>Nicolescu, pp. 143–144</ref> He was again sent to the Assembly in the [[Romanian general election, 1875|1875 election]], during which the "Red" opposition ran as a consolidated [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]] (PNL). During this term, Pogor supported the establishment of a [[Căile Ferate Române|public railways authority]], with compensation for other shareholders.<ref>Nicolescu, p. 181</ref>
Despite the looming PNL threat, Pogor, who had also been reelected chairman of the Iași appellate court,<ref name="gc437"/> and N. Gane were absentee deputies, and were probably convinced that the Catargiu cabinet was about to crumble. Maiorescu, the acting Minister of Education and proponent of an unpopular education reform, was perplexed by their decision: "Gane and Pogor should present themselves in Bucharest ''immediately'' [Maiorescu's italics]! Are we going to engage in politics or not? Is there any solidarity between those of you in Iași and me?"<ref>Ornea (I), p. 267. See also Călinescu, p. 431</ref> Their effective abandon contributed to Maiorescu's resignation in January 1876, then to the arrival in power of a PNL ministry, surprisingly headed by the formerly ultra-"White" Epureanu.<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 267–269</ref>
The ''Junimists'' were soundly defeated in the subsequent [[Romanian general election, 1876|elections of July 1876]].<ref>Ornea (I), p. 270</ref> Pogor managed to preserve his seat in the new legislature, which voted on [[Romanian War of Independence|Romanian independence]] during the [[Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)|War of '77]]. He was thus involved in parliamentary discussions about the thorny issue of antisemitic discrimination favored by the PNL: in early 1878, he was one of the few deputies who questioned the law preventing Romanian Jews from trading in distilled beverages.<ref>{{nl icon}} [http://resolver.kb.nl/resolve?urn=ddd:010873565:mpeg21:pdf "Bijvoegsel. Nationale vergadering van Rumenië"], in ''[[Nieuw Israëlietisch Weekblad]]'', April 4, 1878 (digitized by the [[National Library of the Netherlands]])</ref> Alongside Carp, Gane, and Maiorescu, he enlisted as a member of the reserve militia (or Civic Guard) in Iași, thus serving alongside some members of the Free and Independent Faction.<ref>Maria Totu, ''Garda civică din România 1848—1884'', p. 251. Bucharest: [[Editura Militară]], 1976. {{OCLC|3016368}}</ref>
In 1878, Pogor, who headed the Iași [[credit union]], was also elected to the City Council.<ref name="gc437"/> These was a time of great disorder among the "Whites", who were hard pressed to come up with an answer to the PNL's success. When it seemed that the "White" daily, ''[[Timpul]]'', was about to go under, Pogor joined up with the other ''Junimists'' in making peace with Catargiu, and in gathering funds for the newspaper—their assembly was the first step toward fusing together the major "White" factions.<ref name="sbcadre">{{ro icon}} Silvia Bocancea, [http://www.sferapoliticii.ro/sfera/162/art04-Bocancea.php "Tribulațiile unui partid de cadre. Partidul Conservator (1880)"], in ''[[Sfera Politicii]]'', Nr. 162</ref>
===Conservative Party man, Buddhist scholar, and Iași Mayor=== Pogor was again a ''prelecțiuni'' guest in 1875, by which time the younger ''Junimists'' ([[A. D. Xenopol]], [[Vasile Burlă]] etc.) had taken over the task of popular education. Pogor and I. Negruzzi tacitly accepted their supremacy, and, like them, lectured on topics exclusively linked to the concept of national identity.<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 23–24</ref> Each speaker was to concentrate on one aspect of historical [[acculturation]], from the Romanian contact with [[Byzantine Greeks]] to the reception of German influences, but the schedule was only partly respected.<ref>{{ro icon}} Leonidas Rados, [http://www.history-cluj.ro/Istorie/anuare/AnuarBaritHistorica2008/07%20Leonidas.pdf "Influența greacă în disputele istoriografice din spațiul românesc în a doua jumătate a secolului XIX"], in ''Anuarul Institutului de Istorie George Barițiu, Series Historica'', 2008, [[Romanian Academy]], [http://www.history-cluj.ro/ George Barițiu Institute of History], p. 123</ref>
[[File:Prelecţiuni populare 1879-80.png|thumb|250px|Pogor's handwritten program for the ''prelecțiuni'' program of 1879 and 1880. He sets aside for himself lectures on [[Buddhism]] (''Bud'haïsmul'') and Christianity]] Pursuing his interest in Schopenhauer's work, Pogor discovered the [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] worldview. By the early 1880s, his study of Buddhist concepts had become more systematic: he read the scholarly works of [[Eugène Burnouf]], then popularized Buddhist principles in a ''Convorbiri Literare'' series (1883–1884).<ref name="tv81"/> With Maiorescu, and using German intermediaries, Pogor helped Romanians become acquainted with [[Classical Chinese poetry]]. While Maiorescu gave his touch to ''[[Zhuangzi (book)|Zhuangzi]]'', Pogor rendered an anonymous (and possibly irretrievable) piece, called "Lover Submitting".<ref>{{ro icon}} Constantin Lupeanu, [http://revistaramuri.ro/index.php?id=1303&editie=51&autor=de%20Constantin%20Lupeanu "Interferențe culturale"], in ''[[Ramuri]]'', Nr. 10/2010</ref> In tandem, he looked into [[Sanskrit literature]], translating translations from [[Amaru Shataka|Amaru]].<ref name="dmmodelul"/>
On February 3, 1880, Pogor was one of 88 "White" spokesmen who signed the founding document of Romania's [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880–1918)|Conservative Party]].<ref name="sbcadre"/> The [[Kingdom of Romania]], proclaimed in 1881, was thus effectively ruled by a [[two-party system]]. For three non-consecutive terms, Pogor was the Conservative and ''Junimist'' Mayor of Iași: February 10, 1880 to April 26, 1881; June 7, 1888 to June 7, 1890; May 30, 1892 to November 11, 1894.<ref name="spirituljun"/> He entered history for his creative approach to the [[Romanianization]] measures, specifically those which required all shops to have Romanian-language signs. Although this resonated with the ''Junimist'' idea of standardizing the language, and even though the Moldavian retailers were on the verge of rebelling, Pogor is said to have had "great fun" dealing with the consequences.<ref name="lppruteanu">{{ro icon}} Liviu Papuc, [https://web.archive.org/web/20140714183759/http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/PAPUCoct.html "V. Pogor și legea Pruteanu"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', October 2002</ref> He proposed that all shops still carrying non-essential foreign words be taxed at three times the official rate.<ref name="romlitlegi">{{ro icon}} Reporter, [http://www.romlit.ro/index.pl/n_jurul_unei_legi "Întâlnirile ''României Literare'': În jurul unei legi"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 44/2002</ref>
Cultural history preserves his dialogue with a Jewish merchant, who told him that Romanian had no assimilated word for "liqueurs"; Pogor spontaneously approximated an equivalent, ''licheruri''<ref name="gc437"/> (or even its current form, ''lichioruri'').<ref name="lppruteanu"/> Instead of the French term ''parfumerie'' ("perfume retailer"), he suggested ''parfumeraie''<ref name="romlitlegi"/> or ''parfumăraie''.<ref name="lppruteanu"/> Chaos followed, and the Romanianization campaign was abandoned. In the end, only one firm was touched the experiment, adopting the willingly absurd title of ''Șateaucs aucs fleurs''—a [[Macaronic language|macaronic]] rendition of the French ''Châteaux aux fleurs'' ("Flower Castles").<ref name="lppruteanu"/>
Pogor also took care of various other projects, ensuring that the city was compensated by the central government for having lost its status of state capital: 10 million [[Romanian leu|lei]] entered the city budget (6 of which were compensation from the Romanian state),<ref name="rș239">Șuțu, p. 239</ref> and 8 neighboring estates were merged into the [[Iași metropolitan area|metropolitan area]].<ref name="spirituljun"/> He moved the City Hall into [[Roznovanu Palace]], ordering works to begin on the [[Iași National Theatre]], [[public bathing]] facilities, ten primary schools, and a new Abattoir.<ref name="spirituljun"/> Under Pogor, the streets of Iași were paved with [[macadam]], [[gas lighting]] was extended, and [[sanitation]] works were started.<ref name="spirituljun"/> ''Casa Pogor'' was the city's first electrically-lit building.<ref name="lvvp-fiul"/> His mandates saw the erection of statues honoring the pioneer Moldavian historian [[Miron Costin]] (1888)<ref>{{ro icon}} Radu Moțoc, [http://www.bvau.ro/docs/axislibri/AxisLibri6.pdf "Statuia lui Miron Costin (1633–1691), din Iași"], in the V. A. Urechia Library ''Axis Libri'', Nr. 6, March 2010, p. 73</ref> and the ''Junimist'' poet [[Vasile Alecsandri]] (1890).<ref>{{ro icon}} Laura Bejenaru, [http://astra.iasi.roedu.net/pdf/nr50pag29-31.pdf "Statuia lui Vasile Alecsandri din Iași"], in ''Revista Română'' ([[Asociația Transilvană pentru Literatura Română și Cultura Poporului Român|ASTRA]]), Nr. 4/2007, pp. 29–31; Șuțu, pp. 236–237</ref>
===Later assignments=== Pogor was also a factor in the rapprochement between the Maiorescu ''Junimists'', who had again divorced the Catargiu Conservatives, and the moderate core of the PNL. Although Maiorescu himself rejected a ministerial appointment in the [[Ion Brătianu]] administration, he and the other self-styled "moderate conservatives" backed Brătianu's practical foreign policy. In February 1884, he promised that Pogor and other disgruntled Conservatives ([[Menelas Ghermani]], [[Gheorghe Manu]], [[Anastasie Triandafil]] etc.) would follow him in proclaiming conditional support for Brătianu.<ref>Ornea (I), p. 294</ref> Maiorescu thus saved the government from a likely recall, and was embraced by an enthusiastic Brătianu while the Assembly looked on.<ref>Ornea (I), p. 295</ref> The ''Junimist'' realignment gave the club a permanent representation at the epicenter of Romanian politics. Maiorescu received accolades from the cabinet and, in the [[Romanian general election, 1884|November 1884 election]], his men received nine seats in the Assembly, negotiated upon with the PNL, and three more for "independent" members; Pogor, Iacob Negruzzi, [[Ioan Mire Melik]] and [[Ioan Ianov]] were the ''Junimist'' deputies from Iași.<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 297–300. See also Bacalbașa, p. 370</ref> As noted by Maiorescu, Pogor was somewhat harder to win over by the PNL's cartel: "Even Pogor, who had favored the reunified opposition, has grown tired of their parties and feels that he should stand with us".<ref>Ornea (I), p. 298</ref>
The ''Junimists''{{'}} ambitions were frustrated by Brătianu only months after the election, when he still refused to include members of the club into his administration. ''Junimea'' reverted to independent politics, its conflict with the PNL exacerbated by a personal dispute between Maiorescu and National Liberal politico [[Eugeniu Stătescu]].<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 300–302</ref> Pogor still suggested that ''Junimea'' should back the anti-PNL "United Opposition", betting Maiorescu that the latter would be called into power by the monarch. Maiorescu won this challenge: in early 1888, after a bloody incident in the Assembly sabotaged all communication between the two main parties, Carol appointed Th. Rosetti as Romanian Premier, and an all-''Junimist'' cabinet was in power for just under a year.<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 309–312</ref> In September 1888, alongside [[Dimitrie Ghica-Comănești]] and Ilariu R. Isvoranu, Pogor negotiated an alliance with the mainline Conservatives, allowing Rosetti to secure his office.<ref>"O pagină de istorie", in ''[[Epoca (Romania)|Epoca]]'', February 8 (20), 1889, p. 1</ref>
In the [[Romanian general election, October 1888|election of October]], Pogor did not rally with the Conservative–''Junimist'' caucus, and joined the dissident Liberals of [[Dimitrie Brătianu]], winning at [[ballotage]] for Iași County, Second College.<ref>"Resultatul alegerii colegiului II din Iași", in ''[[Epoca (Romania)|Epoca]]'', October 15 (27), 1888, p. 2</ref> He also continued to be listed as a ''Junimist'', and took another seat in the race for the First College.<ref>"Rezultatul scrutinului de balotagiu. Colegiul I-u al Camerei", in ''[[Epoca (Romania)|Epoca]]'', October 21 (November 2), 1888, p. 1</ref> Rosetti's cabinet was by then supported by the Conservatives, but fell when a Conservative deputy, [[Nicolae Moret Blaremberg]], stirred political conflicts by proposing to indict the PNL's former governing team—such a project was regarded by Rosetti and the ''Junimists'' as entirely demagogic.<ref>Ornea (I), p. 315</ref> Both Pogor and Maiorescu were also partly responsible for the PNL's return to power: they abstained form voting against the [[motion of no confidence]] which toppled Rosetti.<ref>"Votul de ierĭ", in ''[[România Liberă]]'', April 1 (13), 1888, p. 1</ref>
From 1889 to 1890, during the ''Junimists''{{'}} reestablishment as an independent party, and again after the [[Romanian general election, 1891|1891 election]], Pogor was Vice President of the Assembly.<ref>Călinescu, pp. 436, 437, 441</ref> As Panu recalls, he was making a mockery of this assignment: he doodled caricatures of his colleagues, pulled pranks on them "just like in school", and satirized parliamentary procedures with parody statements (such as "the motion has been defeated with a crushing minority").<ref name="gc441"/> In the early 1890s, he was firmly committed to the Conservative Party, and served on its Iași committee—alongside Ianov, [[Grigore Sturdza]], [[A. C. Cuza]], [[Alecu D. Holban]], [[Nicolae Culianu]], and [[Petru Th. Missir]].<ref>Șuțu, pp. 1–3</ref> Pogor was also drafted into the panel which negotiated an alliance with the [[Radical Party (Romania)|Radical Party]] before the [[Romanian local elections, 1895|county elections of September 1895]], and then into the nomination committee for the [[Romanian general election, 1895|general election]].<ref>Șuțu, pp. 4–6</ref>
In December 1897, Pogor and his ''Junimist'' colleagues again withdrew from the Conservative caucus, only to return before the [[Romanian local elections, 1899|1899 county election]], in which Pogor and Missir stood as candidates.<ref>Șuțu, pp. 13–14</ref> By November 1900, when the Conservatives and ''Junimists'' finally merged into one party, Pogor was again the chairman of the credit union. He also became a member of Iași's Conservative Party steering committee, involving himself in strategy planning ahead of the [[Romanian general election, 1901|1901 general election]].<ref>Șuțu, pp. 18–20, 113</ref> Having poorly invested his own sizable fortune, he found himself pestered by his many creditors.<ref name="gc437"/> One of his biographers, Liviu Papuc, noted that, overall, the first ''Junimist'' generation ran into financial trouble, and that Pogor ended his career on an "even score" with life.<ref>{{ro icon}} Liviu Papuc, [https://web.archive.org/web/20131109115143/http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/PAPUCdec6.html "Ioan M. Melik sau simțul practic la Junimea"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', December 2006</ref> In 1901, he sold ''Casa Pogor'' to socialite Maria Moruzi.<ref name="cccasele4"/><ref name="siher">Sorin Iftimi, "Heraldică și arhitectură", in ''Monumentul'', Vol. VII, 2006, pp. 502–504</ref> The ''Junimist'' co-founder died on March 20, 1906, at his other address—a vineyard in the Iași suburb of Bucium;<ref name="gc437"/> according to his fellow Conservative Rudolf Șuțu, he "passed on among his family, placid and smiling, as he had lived".<ref name="rș239"/> His tomb is located in [[Eternitatea cemetery]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Felix Guzga, [http://www.ziaruldeiasi.ro/local/primaria-a-facut-recensamintul-personalitatilor-de-la-eternitatea~ni43kn "Primăria a făcut recensamîntul personalităților de la ''Eternitatea''"], in ''[[Ziarul de Iași]]'', August 18, 2006</ref>
==Work==
===Anti-dogmatic ''Junimism'' and Parnassian poetry=== Pogor's anti-dogmatism precluded his engagement on the more serious side of ''Junimism''. When approving of ''Junimea''{{'}}s name, he staged a fake baptism, asking those present to pledge that they would "renounce pedantry".<ref>Ornea (I), p. 18; Vianu, p. 18</ref> His philosophical dilettantism was still influential at ''Junimea'': I. Negruzzi recalled that, during the club's sessions, Pogor systematically prevented historians and philologists from reporting on their concrete finds, and only listened to the generic conclusions.<ref>Vianu, p. 12</ref> As Vianu notes, Pogor himself was virtually incapable of "choosing" between the many subjects that interested him at any one time.<ref name="tv81"/> It is possible that Pogor is the author of an anonymous poem celebrating his own idleness and contrariness: {{Verse translation| {{lang|ro|Simt o mare fericire de-a sta singur în tăcere, Deși stricta convenință mă silește-a fi la bal, Căci sunt leneș de natură și mă legăn cu plăcere Într-o dulce somnolență pe al visurilor val.}}<ref>Călinescu, pp. 437–438</ref> | I will get my greatest joy sitting here alone and quiet, While that strictest social standard wants me to attend a ball, For I'm lazy by my nature and will loll down here with pleasure Carried by sweet drowsiness, rocking on the waves of dreams.}}
While the ''caracudă'' rejoiced, the club's more idealistic visitors were disturbed by Pogor's antics. On these grounds, Pogor fully supported only the most subversive and eccentric manifestations of ''Junimist'' literature. He was the only one in the group not to approve of poet laureate [[Vasile Alecsandri]]. Although he later helped build the Alecsandri monument, he once shouted out that Alecsandri had "a grocer's taste" in art.<ref>Cioculescu, p. 278</ref> Instead, Pogor loved the work of peasant storyteller [[Ion Creangă]], and, to the indignation of some other club members, encouraged him to read aloud from his [[erotic literature]] series, "the corrosives".<ref>Ornea (II), pp. 230, 231, 236; Vianu, p. 211</ref> Later, Pogor welcomed in and shed a spotlight on the cynical, streetwise, humorist [[Ion Luca Caragiale]], who was a passing guest at ''Junimea''. According to Șerban Cioculescu, Pogor differed from Eminescu in that he "freely enjoyed [Caragiale's] charming spontaneity and temperamental zigzags."<ref>Cioculescu, pp. 5–6</ref> Pogor's nonconformism could target even the group's doyen, Maiorescu. He coined the disparaging nickname ''Muierescu'' (from ''muiere'', "broad", in reference to his colleague's alleged sexual misconduct).<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Eugen Lungu]], [http://www.sud-est.md/numere/20061123/article_4/ "Istorie și intimitate"], in ''[[Revista Sud-Est]]'', Nr. 4/2006</ref>
His own work in poetry was reviewed with little sympathy by later critics and historians. They dismiss his original pieces as "anodyne"<ref>Ornea (I), p. 42</ref> and not up to the test of time,<ref>Călinescu, pp. 397, 437</ref> although, as Rudolf Șuțu argues, they too helped engineer a [[literary language]].<ref>Șuțu, pp. 239–240</ref> Pogor was a Romanian [[Parnassianism|Parnassian]], reworking classical themes and seeking formal purity,<ref name="tv82">Vianu, p. 82</ref> and was especially influenced by Baudelaire and by [[Théophile Gautier]].<ref name="gc437"/> His verse includes an homage to ''[[Melencolia I]]'', the famous engraving by [[Albrecht Dürer]]—similarly titled ''Melancolie''. George Călinescu focuses his comments on the poem's atmospheric quality, noting that its "French structure" is exceptional in the ''Junimist'' context. The other ''Junimea'' bards, he suggests, still favored "accessible" poetry of the [[Young Germany]] kind.<ref name="gc437"/> Beyond the Parnassian poems, Pogor applied his wit (or, as critic [[Cosmin Ciotloș]] calls it, "unbelievably malicious spirit") to the realm of parody. His joke poem, ''Vedenia'' ("The Apparition"), managed to impress rival Eminescu, who made the effort of transcribing it in his records of ''Junimea'' meetings.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Cosmin Ciotloș]], [http://www.zf.ro/ziarul-de-duminica/vremuri-parodice-3311325/ "Vremuri parodice"], in ''[[Ziarul Financiar]]'', October 14, 2008</ref>
Pogor's translation also produced mixed results. Scholar [[Dan Mănucă]] believes that the Romanian author found Baudelaire to be "more of a picturesque eccentric and, certainly, not at all a literary innovator"; for this reason, he only looked to Baudelaire's tamer writings, that excluded "scandal".<ref name="dmmodelul"/> Pogor's version of Hugo's "[[La Légende des siècles|Conscience]]" made a positive impression, and was quoted by [[Grigore Pletosu]] in his [[propaedeutics]] to philosophy (1899).<ref>{{ro icon}} Nicu, [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/transilvania/1899/BCUCLUJ_FP_279996_1899_030_009.pdf "Șciință literatură și artă. Bibliografie. Literatura didactică"], in ''Transilvania'', Nr. 9/1899, p. 305 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> Pogor's other projects were often panned by experts. Classicist Nicolae Laslo sees Pogor's version of Horatian verse as mostly failed, "with lots of gaucheries and naivetes."<ref name="nlhoratiu537"/> The Pogor–Skelitti rendition of Goethe, although verified by the two ''Junimists'' through previous French versions ([[Gérard de Nerval]], Henri Blaze),<ref name="dmmodelul"/> is also considered problematic. [[German studies|Germanist]] Corina Jiva indicates that they had only a vague understanding of the German words they translated into Romanian.<ref name="cjnoica"/> Pogor may have been aware of the shortcomings, since, after Skelitti died, ''Convorbiri'' issued a second version of ''Faust I''. It modified the first edition, and only credited one author: Pogor.<ref name="dmmodelul"/>
===Pogor on religion and nationality=== Vasile Pogor's roots were in [[Romanian Orthodox Church|Romanian Orthodoxy]]: his father was ''[[ktitor]]'' of the Misești Church.<ref name="gc92"/> Pogor Jr was himself a student of Christian history, but his main focus was on [[Judaism]], the [[Hebrew Bible]], and the Christian [[Old Testament]]. He kept detailed notes on the minutiae of biblical lore, making notes about [[Gog and Magog]], the ''[[Kinnor]]'', the ''[[Purim]]'' etc.<ref name="gc437, 1000">Călinescu, pp. 437, 1000</ref> Albeit fascinated by Jewish and Buddhist practices, the poet was mainly a [[Freethought|Freethinker]], seen by Vianu as "of a Voltairian and [[Positivism|Positivist]] extraction."<ref name="tv81"/> The theories of [[Auguste Comte]] and positivist language in general were welcomed by Pogor and the other core ''Junimists'' even though, as Zigu Ornea notes, the leading exponents of Positivist discourse were secondary ''Junimists'' ([[Nicolae Xenopol]], [[George Panu]]).<ref>Ornea (I), p. 5</ref>
Pogor attacked religion as a lifeless institution, as seen in his poem ''Magnitudo parri'', credited by some as his masterpiece.<ref name="tv81"/> For Pogor, a swallow's effort to raise its offspring is more worthy of attention than the [[Byzantine architecture|Byzantine church]] looming over its nest: {{Verse translation| {{lang|ro|Cântarea păsăruicii e bolta cea divină! Religiuni, popoare pot a se nimici; Lipsească chiar credința sub bolta bizantină — ::Altarul este-aci!}}<ref name="tv82"/> | The tiny bird's own singing is a vault by God! Vanish religions, peoples; Perish faith itself under the Byzantine arch — ::That altar, it is here!}}
Historian [[Balázs Trencsényi]] argues that Vasile Pogor, like the other ''Junimist'' doyens, engineered "an [[Epistemology|epistemological]] break" with the predominating school of [[Romantic nationalism]], as well as with the 18th-century ''[[philosophes]]'', introducing instead Positivist and [[Sociological naturalism|naturalistic]] approaches to social science.<ref>Trencsényi, pp. 156–157</ref> Taking his inspiration from Buckle, Pogor leaned toward [[environmental determinism]] as an explanation of historical processes. "Warmer" areas, he claimed, were predisposed to [[despotism]], no matter how advanced there were materially. Trencsényi focuses on Pogor's proposal to separate the material and spiritual growth of a nation, thus contextualizing the ''Junimist'' critique of Romania's [[Westernization]]: "[Pogor's views] served as a critical perspective to judge societies which reached a certain level of socio-economic modernity without an overall mental adaptation to the Western patterns."<ref>Trencsényi, p. 157</ref>
Although not explicitly extended to the Romanian paradigm, Pogor's introduction to Buckle formed an integral part of the ''Junimist'' discourse about [[nation building]]. As Ornea notes, Pogor struck the typical ''Junimist'' note with his critique of revolutionary doctrines, in pronouncements such as: "had politicians not been meddling in to prevent the natural flow of things, progress would have occurred at a quicker pace".<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 167–168</ref> Also according to Ornea, the study endures as both a relevant contribution to ''Junimism'' and a facet of [[Romanian philosophy]] in the 1870s.<ref>Ornea (I), pp. 60, 157, 167–168</ref> Trencsényi sees a direct link between the survival of "despotism" in post-modernization, as surveyed by Buckle and Pogor, and the ''Junimists''{{'}} rejection of Romania's top-to-bottom Westernization by the liberals. Pogor's vague critique is expanded upon by Th. Rosetti. Rosetti's essays postulate the unrelenting "primitivism" of Romanian society. The liberals stand accused of not having promoted a gradual, "authentic", modernization of Romanian institutions, and of having imposed their "hybrid forms" on the Romanian psyche.<ref>Trencsényi, pp. 157–158</ref>
Maiorescu himself suggested that Pogor's Bucklean discovery facilitated ''Junimism''{{'}}s transformation into a socio-political movement. Other such influences came from Schopenhauer, and from [[John Stuart Mill]]'s ''[[The Subjection of Women|Subjection of Women]]''.<ref>Ornea (I), p. 157</ref> Buckle influenced the main ''Junimist'' historical narratives, from Maiorescu's historical lectures to A. D. Xenopol's own ''History of Civilizations''.<ref name="arideologia13"/> Pogor's own belief, namely that Romania was essentially peripheral to [[Culture of Europe|European civilization]], was not readily welcomed by the [[National conservatism|national conservative]] faction at ''Junimea''. A glimpse of this is provided by a maverick ''Junimist'', George Panu, as a purported clash between Pogor and the [[Nativism (politics)|autochthonist]] Eminescu. According to Panu, Pogor openly ridiculed national historians: "What's all this about the history of the Romanians? Can't you see that we have no history? A people which has no literature, art, or past civilization—such a people is not worth the attention of historians... At a time when France could produce [[Molière]] and [[Jean Racine|Racine]] the Romanians were in a state of utter barbarism."<ref name="lb39">[[Lucian Boia]], ''History and Myth in Romanian Consciousness'', p. 39. Budapest & New York City: [[Central European University Press]], 2001. {{ISBN|963-9116-96-3}}</ref> Eminescu retorted, promptly and (Panu notes) violently: "What you call barbarism, I call the settled wisdom of a people that develops in conformity with its own genius and shuns any mixing with foreigners"<ref name="lb39"/> (alternatively translated as: "the wisdom of a nation, which progresses according to the rhythm of its own genius, away from any foreign interference").<ref name="amd106">Ana Maria Dobre, "Revisiting Historical and Cultural Myths and Clichés. The Romanian Case of Nation State Building", in [[Raymond Detrez]], Barbara Segaert (eds.), ''Europe and the Historical Legacies in the Balkans. Europe Plurielle – Multiple Europes, 40'', p. 106. Brussels etc.: [[Peter Lang (publishing company)|Peter Lang]], 2008. {{ISBN|978-90-5201-374-9}}</ref>
Factual or merely symbolic, this showdown has been interpreted by later historians as a good introduction to the conflicting perspectives on Romanian nationhood. In 1997, scholar [[Lucian Boia]] suggested: "What we find summarized in these few lines is the great dilemma which has divided Romanian society for the last two centuries."<ref name="lb39"/> Political scientist Ana Maria Dobre, who connects Pogor's supposed comments with Maiorescu's dismissal of early Romanian history as "oriental barbarism", introduces the Pogor–Eminescu exchange as "a profound dichotomy opposing the defenders of the traditional, specific national values of organization and the supporters of an unconditional modernisation and adaptation to the occidental model in order to depart from a rudimentary type of society."<ref name="amd106"/>
==Legacy== Visual portrayals of Pogor include a sketch by [[Eugen N. Ghika-Budești]], first published in 1895. It shows the ''Junimist'' relaxing among lewd [[devadasi]]s, "leaving behind him the boredom that is the Vice President's chair".<ref name="msrsiècle">{{ro icon}} Mihai Sorin Rădulescu, [http://www.romlit.ro/index.pl/un_pictor_fin_de_sicle "Un pictor fin de siècle"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 17/2009</ref> A posthumous bust, the work of Iași sculptor [[Dan Covătaru]], was also exhibited in the city.<ref>{{ro icon}} Valentin Ciucă, [http://insemnariiesene.ro/insemnari_iesene-nr.2%28octombrie%292009.pdf "Resursele vitale ale sculpturii..."], in ''Însemnări Ieșene'', Nr. 2/2009, p. 52</ref> In literature, Eminescu's 1878 parody of the ''[[Odyssey]]'', referencing a moment of ''Junimist'' crisis, portrays Pogor as "the swineherd Pogoros" (the club's own [[Eumaeus]]).<ref>Traian Diaconescu, "Antropomorfism. Discurs parodic și funcții ludice", in Viorica S. Constantinescu, Cornelia Viziteu, Lucia Cifor (eds.), ''Studii Eminescologice, 13'', p. 28. Cluj-Napoca: Editura Clusium, 2011</ref> In addition to his affectionate memoirs, Iacob Negruzzi also made Pogor the subject of an 1872 poem: {{Verse translation| {{lang|ro|Eu sunt eroul straniu cu locuința-n Iași, De o statură mică, la minte prea poznaș, Ce planuri urieșe și multe născocește Dar vecinic din aceste nici unul nu-mplinește.}}<ref name="gc437"/> | I am that strange hero, and resident of Iași, A man so small in stature, too impish is his mind, Who will imagine plans so very grand and wide But never does he manage to carry out just one.}}
Pogor's work as poet and theorist was largely forgotten by later generations. This was noted by ''Junimea'' anthologist [[Eugen Lovinescu]], who made the conscious effort of reviving the deterministic Parnassian, alongside other "minor ''Junimists''", to evidence "what they still have that's viable."<ref name="arideologia13"/> Pogor left one son, Vasile Panopol, a once-famous historiographer of Iași.<ref name="msrsiècle"/><ref name="icstr">{{ro icon}} Ioana Cioflâncă, [http://ieseanul.gandul.info/saptamanal/stralucirea-pierduta-a-strazii-lapusneanu-2609708 "Strălucirea pierdută a Străzii Lăpușneanu"], in ''[[Ieșeanul]]'', May 5, 2008</ref> Born out of wedlock, Panopol had a similar taste for pranks, and belonged to the infamous "black gang" of rebellious aristocrats.<ref name="icstr"/> While the Pogor book collection was on sale, and divided, soon after its owner died,<ref name="tv81"/> ''Casa Pogor'' survives as a major historical landmark of Iași. After the Moruzi purchase, it became the childhood home of Maria Moruzi's son by [[Ion I. C. Brătianu]], the renowned historian [[Gheorghe I. Brătianu]].<ref name="cccasele4"/><ref>{{ro icon}} Lucian Nastasă, [http://www.history-cluj.ro/Istorie/cercet/Nastasa/SuveraniiUniversitatilorI.pdf ''"Suveranii" universităților românești. Mecanisme de selecție și promovare a elitei intelectuale''], Vol. I, [[Editura Limes]], Cluj-Napoca, 2007, pp. 129, 138. {{ISBN|978-973-726-278-3}}</ref> The new owners made structural changes, and replaced the Pogor family monograms with Moruzi arms.<ref name="siher"/>
In the late 1930s, Brătianu rented ''Casa Pogor'' to the Iași's Royal Commissioner, and, during [[World War II]], it was confiscated by [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] representatives.<ref name="cccasele4"/> [[Nationalization in Romania|Nationalized]] during the first decades of [[Communist Romania]], it was refurbished by the state only after 1968.<ref name="cccasele4"/> It was ultimately created a museum in 1972<ref name="cccasele4"/> or 1973,<ref name="Ornea I, p. 34"/> and is a regional center of the [[Museum of Romanian Literature]] network (supervising other monuments, including, as of 1995, the Negruzzi Memorial House of [[Trifești, Iași|Trifești]]).<ref>{{ro icon}} Constantin Coroiu, [http://www.romlit.ro/index.pl/n_satul_negruzzetilor "În satul Negruzzeștilor"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 33/2005</ref> The main exhibit hall is mainly known for its Eminescu memorabilia, including the poet's [[death mask]].<ref name="cccasele4"/> Its tunnels and its halls have hosted art experiments, including an adaptation of [[Mircea Eliade]]'s ''[[Domnișoara Christina]]'' (1999),<ref>{{ro icon}} Mac Linscott Ricketts, [http://www.revistaorizont.ro/arhiva/martie2012.pdf "Spectacolul Eliade"], in ''[[Orizont]]'', Nr. 3/2012, p. 11</ref> an introduction to [[Music of Senegal|Senegalese music]] (2006),<ref>{{ro icon}} Claudia Craiu, [http://www.ziaruldeiasi.ro/pulsul-orasului/povesti-si-ritmuri-africane-astazi-la-casa-pogor~ni44pr "Povești și ritmuri africane, astăzi, la Casa Pogor"], in ''[[Ziarul de Iași]]'', October 19, 2006</ref> and a colloquium of the international [[avant-garde]] (2008).<ref>{{ro icon}} Ion Cocora, [http://www.revistaluceafarul.ro/index.html?id=522&editie=28 "Un pictor din mileniul trei"], in ''[[Luceafărul (magazine)|Luceafărul]]'', Nr. 26/2008</ref>
Pogor has a following in the Romanian-speaking literary communities of [[Bessarabia]], most of which is now the independent state of [[Moldova]]. During the period of Soviet rule in Bessarabia (the [[Moldavian SSR]]), references to Romanian cultural assets were usually shunned; this changed in the late 1980s, when Bessarabian cultural magazines were allowed to republish samples of classical Romanian literature. ''Nistru'' journal inaugurated the trend in 1988, choosing Pogor as the first contributor to revive. According to Moldovan essayist Maria Șleahtițchi: "Why the magazine's editors should have selected such a minor writer is the stuff of rhetorical questions."<ref>{{ro icon}} Maria Șleahtițchi, [http://www.revista-discobolul.ro/ar/Discobol_2008_10_11_12.pdf "Pe marginea exilului: între mama si tata"], in ''Discobolul'', Nr. 130–131–132/2008, p. 92</ref>
